awd_titl_txt: CRII: RI: Matching Image Features with Correctness Predictions
awd_abstract_narration:
The project develops methods for measuring the correctness of image-feature correspondences, which helps systems to identify good and bad correspondences. The project investigates robust estimators and 3D-point cloud compression algorithms that leverage the correctness measures of image-feature correspondences to increase their effectiveness. The developed methods can have many applications, such as image stitching for the creation of panoramas, 3D model reconstruction from photo collections, vision-based navigation in self-driving cars and robots, and augmented reality. The project integrates research with education by developing 3D computer vision courses and involving undergraduate and graduate students in this fundamental research effort. 

This research develops theoretically grounded confidence measures for classifiers using the statistical theory of extreme values. In particular, the project investigates confidence measures for the nearest neighbor classifier, a widely used classifier in many computer vision and other applications. The project investigates the confidence measures in two computer vison tasks: robust estimation and scene compression. The research focuses on using the developed confidence measures to enable the adaptive use of non-minimal samples for hypotheses generation and fast convergence in RANSAC-based estimators. Furthermore, the project develops a scene-compression algorithm based on a convex optimization method, of which objective function considers spatial coverage and visual distinctiveness. The project studies ways to enforce visual distinctiveness using confidence measures derived from this work and applies them to different applications to demonstrate the robustness and efficiency of estimating the correctness of image-feature correspondences.

por.por_cntn:
Several problems in computer vision and other applications require finding matching features as an intermediate step. From a pattern recognition point of view, finding matching correspondences can be modeled as a nearest neighbor classification process; however, the impact of noise leads to outlier correspondences, with potentially catastrophic consequences in applications such as scene reconstruction, structure from motion (SfN), or visual-based navigation, to mention a few. Extracting reliable correspondences in an efficient manner is a difficult challenge. This project addressed it by developing efficient methods for measuring the confidence of matching correspondences, which helps systems to identify good and bad correspondences. The project investigated robust estimators and 3D point cloud compression algorithms based on those confidence measures.

The major outcomes of the project are as follows:

(1)  Development of confidence measures for classifiers. The focus has been on confidence measures for the nearest neighbor classifier, a widely used classifier in many computer vision applications and others.

(1.a)  The first framework developed uses confidence measures for the robust estimation of geometrical models from pairs of images. Through confidence measures it is possible to adaptively form non-minimal sets of noisy inliers (i.e., nearest neighbor image-features correspondences), which lead to less noisy model hypothesis generations, and thus, faster convergence of RANSAC-based estimators.

(1.b)  The second framework developed uses confidence measures for the robust discovery of overlapping image pairs in large-scale structure from motion (SfM) pipelines. Establishing overlapping image pairs provides the needed matching graph for the downstream dense reconstruction process. Confidence measures combined with scene priors are used to guide the search for generating the matching graph with a higher accuracy and less demanding computing needs.

(2)  Development of confidence measures for scene (3D point cloud) compression. The framework introduces a scene-compression algorithm based on an objective function that considers spatial coverage and distinctiveness of the representation. This leads to a convex optimization which is efficient to solve, has a unique solution, and enforces visual distinctiveness based on confidence measures. The method leads to improved computational efficiency, as well as accuracy in downstream applications (e.g., vision-based navigation).

This work has direct relevance to many applications, like image stitching for the creation of panoramas, 3D model reconstruction from photo collections, vision-based navigation in self-driving cars and robots, as well as virtual and augmented reality. Graduate and undergraduate students were involved in the project, allowing them to gain experience in cutting-edge technology areas. Publications and presentations at international conferences have been used to disseminate the research results. The project also integrated research with education through the development of courses with a focus on 3D computer vision.
